title: JavaLinkedList - Q0001
text: Which package contains the LinkedList class?
explanation: The LinkedList class is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0002
text: Which interface does LinkedList implement?
explanation: LinkedList implements List, Deque, and Queue interfaces.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0003
text: What type of data structure does LinkedList use internally?
explanation: LinkedList uses a doubly linked list internally to store elements.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0004
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and null elements?

options.text: LinkedList allows only one null element
LinkedList does not allow null elements

explanation: LinkedList allows multiple null elements.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0005
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and duplicates?

options.text: LinkedList throws an exception for duplicates

explanation: LinkedList allows duplicate elements.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0006
text: Which of the following constructors creates an empty LinkedList?
explanation: The no-argument constructor creates an empty LinkedList.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0007
text: Which of the following methods adds an element to the end of a LinkedList?
explanation: All these methods can add an element to the end of a LinkedList.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0008
text: Which of the following methods adds an element at the beginning of a LinkedList?
explanation: All these methods can add an element at the beginning of a LinkedList.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0009
text: Which of the following methods removes the first element of a LinkedList?
explanation: All these methods remove the first element of a LinkedList.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0010
text: Which of the following methods removes the last element of a LinkedList?
explanation: removeLast() and pollLast() remove the last element of a LinkedList.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0011
text: Which of the following methods retrieves but does not remove the first element?
explanation: peek(), getFirst(), and element() retrieve but do not remove the first element.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0012
text: Which of the following methods retrieves but does not remove the last element?
explanation: peekLast() and getLast() retrieve but do not remove the last element.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0013
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and random access?

options.text: LinkedList does not support fast random access
LinkedList provides O(log n) random access
LinkedList provides O(1) access for all elements

explanation: LinkedList does not support fast random access; accessing elements is O(n).

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and insertion?

options.text: Insertion at the beginning or end is O(1)
Insertion at the beginning or end is O(n)

explanation: Insertion at the beginning or end of a LinkedList is O(1).

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and removal?

options.text: Removing first or last element is O(1)
Removing first or last element is O(n)

explanation: Removing the first or last element in a LinkedList is O(1).

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and iteration?
explanation: LinkedList supports both Iterator and ListIterator for traversal.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and fail-fast behavior?
explanation: LinkedList iterators are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and synchronization?
explanation: LinkedList is not synchronized and is not thread-safe by default.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0019
text: Which of the following methods can be used to synchronize a LinkedList?
explanation: The Collections.synchronizedList() method returns a synchronized version of the list.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and memory usage?

options.text: LinkedList uses more memory than ArrayList
LinkedList uses less memory than ArrayList
LinkedList and ArrayList use the same memory
LinkedList memory usage depends on capacity

explanation: LinkedList uses more memory because each node stores references to previous and next elements.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and random access performance?

options.text: LinkedList provides O(log n) random access

explanation: LinkedList provides O(n) random access because it must traverse nodes sequentially.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and insertion at arbitrary positions?

options.text: Insertion at arbitrary positions is O(n)
Insertion at arbitrary positions is O(1)
Insertion at arbitrary positions is O(log n)
Insertion at arbitrary positions is O(n^2)

explanation: Insertion at arbitrary positions requires traversal, making it O(n).

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and removal from arbitrary positions?

options.text: Removal from arbitrary positions is O(n)
Removal from arbitrary positions is O(1)
Removal from arbitrary positions is O(log n)
Removal from arbitrary positions is O(n^2)

explanation: Removing an element from an arbitrary position requires traversal, making it O(n).

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and iteration performance?
explanation: Iterating through a LinkedList requires visiting each node, making it O(n).

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and capacity?

options.text: LinkedList has a default capacity of 10

explanation: LinkedList has no fixed capacity because it grows dynamically as nodes are added.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and RandomAccess interface?

options.text: LinkedList implements RandomAccess for first and last elements only

explanation: LinkedList does not implement RandomAccess because it does not support fast random access.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and serialization?

options.text: LinkedList cannot be written to a stream

explanation: LinkedList implements Serializable, allowing it to be serialized.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and cloning?
explanation: LinkedList supports shallow cloning using the clone() method.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and equals()?
explanation: The equals() method compares elements in order for equality.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and hashCode()?
explanation: The hashCode() of a LinkedList depends on the hash codes of its elements.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and immutability?
explanation: LinkedList is mutable; elements can be added, removed, or modified.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and sorting?

options.text: LinkedList can be sorted using Collections.sort()

explanation: LinkedList can be sorted using Collections.sort() or List.sort().

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and Streams?
explanation: LinkedList supports both stream() and parallelStream() methods for stream processing.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and toArray()?

options.text: toArray() converts the list to an array

explanation: The toArray() method converts the LinkedList into an array.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and descendingIterator()?

options.text: descendingIterator() returns an iterator in reverse order

explanation: The descendingIterator() method returns an iterator that traverses the list in reverse order.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and peek()?

options.text: peek() retrieves but does not remove the head element

explanation: The peek() method retrieves but does not remove the head element of the list.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and poll()?

options.text: poll() retrieves and removes the head element
poll() retrieves but does not remove the head element

explanation: The poll() method retrieves and removes the head element of the list.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and offer()?

options.text: offer() adds an element to the end of the list

explanation: The offer() method adds an element to the end of the list.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and push()?

options.text: push() adds an element to the front of the list
push() adds an element to the end of the list

explanation: The push() method adds an element to the front of the list, similar to a stack push operation.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and pop()?

options.text: pop() removes and returns the first element
pop() removes and returns the last element

explanation: The pop() method removes and returns the first element of the list.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and stack behavior?

options.text: LinkedList can be used as a stack using push() and pop()
LinkedList cannot be used as a stack
LinkedList can only be used as a queue
LinkedList can only be used as a deque

explanation: LinkedList can act as a stack using push() and pop() methods.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and queue behavior?

options.text: LinkedList can be used as a queue using offer() and poll()
LinkedList cannot be used as a queue
LinkedList can only be used as a stack
LinkedList can only be used as a list

explanation: LinkedList can act as a queue using offer() and poll() methods.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and deque behavior?
explanation: LinkedList implements the Deque interface, supporting double-ended operations.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and null handling?

options.text: LinkedList allows only one null element
LinkedList does not allow null elements

explanation: LinkedList allows multiple null elements.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and removeFirstOccurrence()?

options.text: removeFirstOccurrence() removes the first matching element
removeFirstOccurrence() removes the last matching element

explanation: The removeFirstOccurrence() method removes the first occurrence of the specified element.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and removeLastOccurrence()?

options.text: removeLastOccurrence() removes the last matching element
removeLastOccurrence() removes the first matching element

explanation: The removeLastOccurrence() method removes the last occurrence of the specified element.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and forEach()?

options.text: forEach() performs an action for each element

explanation: The forEach() method performs the specified action for each element in the list.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and replaceAll()?

options.text: replaceAll() replaces each element using a unary operator
replaceAll() replaces all elements with null

explanation: The replaceAll() method replaces each element using the provided unary operator.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedList and sort()?

options.text: sort() sorts elements using a comparator

explanation: The sort() method sorts elements using the specified comparator.

title: JavaLinkedList - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes LinkedList?

options.text: A doubly linked list implementation of the List and Deque interfaces

explanation: LinkedList is a doubly linked list implementation of the List and Deque interfaces.
